source.query: landmine anti rotation press muscles worked
source.raw_text:
The Landmine Anti-Rotation Press works your shoulders (deltoids), chest (pectorals), triceps, and crucially, your entire core (obliques, abs, deep stabilizers) to prevent torso rotation as you press the angled barbell, building unilateral pushing strength and core stability through a single-arm, diagonal pushing movement pattern. It’s a functional exercise that challenges your body to resist movement, improving posture and athletic power by locking down your hips and spine while your arms work. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Pushing): 

    • Deltoids: Especially anterior (front) and medial (side) heads. 
    • Pectoralis Major (Chest): Assists in pushing the weight forward. 
    • Triceps: Extend the elbow to lock out the press. 

• Stabilizers (Anti-Rotation & Core): 

    • Obliques: Work intensely to prevent your torso from twisting. 
    • Rectus Abdominis & Transverse Abdominis: Brace to keep your spine stable. 
    • Glutes: Engage to keep your hips stable and prevent tilting. 
    • Serratus Anterior: Stabilizes the shoulder blade, crucial for a smooth bar path. [1, 2, 3, 6, 7]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Setup: Stand or kneel (half-kneeling is common) facing the landmine, holding one end of the barbell with one hand at chest height. 
2. The Press: Brace your core and glutes, then press the barbell diagonally forward and up, extending your arm fully. 
3. Anti-Rotation: Actively resist the bar pulling your torso to the side; keep your hips and shoulders square to the front. 
4. Return: Control the weight back down in the same angled path. 
5. Pattern: A single-arm diagonal press that forces anti-rotation, challenging core stability and fixing strength imbalances. [1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 9]  

**Citations:**
